questions.text: Based on the disease shown in the image, which of the following specimens would the filarial worms be absent?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis, and the filarial worms cannot be demonstrated in saliva.

Lymphatic filariasis occurs due to the transmission of W.bancrofti by the bite of Culex mosquitoes. The third stage larval forms from the mosquito enter the lymphatics and lymph nodes where they develop into adult worms. The adult worms become sexually mature and mate to release microfilariae which enter the peripheral circulation.

The disease initially causes acute attacks of lymphangitis and lymphadenitis. Early treatment may even cure the disease. The lymphedema may gradually worsen and get associated with the thickening of the skin and fibrosis of lymph vessels or blockage by adult worms. Hydrocele is another common manifestation that occurs due to lymphatic obstruction.

Microfilaria can be demonstrated in blood, chylous urine, exudate of lymph varix, and hydrocele fluid, however, peripheral blood is the preferred choice. The examination of a thick and thin blood smear stained with Giemsa stain shows the microfilaria. Other methods are by examining the unstained blood under a microscope for the actively motile microfilariae and by acridine orange-microhematocrit tube technique.

The best time to collect the blood samples is at night, between 10 pm and 4 am as they are nocturnally periodic.

DEC provocation test: In this test, a small dose of DEC is given 20-50 minutes before sample collection so that the microfilaria appears in the blood even during the daytime. 

The image below shows the life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti.

*Note:

  • W.bancrofti causes Bancroftian filariasis and is transmitted by Culex quinquefasciatus (C. fatigans). In India, Wuchereria bancrofti is the commonest cause of filariasis.
  • B. malayi causes Burgian filariasis and the vector is the Mansonia mosquito.

Related Pearl: Filarial worms and their morphology

questions.text: A farmer with a history of flea bite in a godown presents with the features of high fever, painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, vomiting and diarrhea and hypotension. Smears prepared from the discharge of these swellings revealed bacteria with bipolar staining. Which stain will help in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever, chills, lymphadenopathy, and a smear showing bipolar staining of bacteria is highly suggestive of bubonic plague caused by Yersinia pestis. The stain used for this organism is the Wayson stain containing methylene blue.

Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis. It is a gram-negative, non-motile, coccobacillus. The reservoirs of infection are wild rodents like field mice, gerbils, skunks, etc. In India, the gerbil (Tatera indica) is the main reservoir. The important vector of plague is rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis).

Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague. 

Human plague mainly presents as:

Bubonic plague- This is the most common type of disease. The patient develops a sudden fever, chills, headache, and painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes. Bubonic plague cannot spread from person to person as the bacilli are locked up in the buboes and do not find a way or easy exit.

Pneumonic plague- It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague. 

Septicemic plague- It occurs when the infection spreads to the blood.

Laboratory diagnosis- Microscopy reveals bacteria that show characteristic bipolar staining or safety pin appearance when stained with Wayson's stain. Antibodies to the F1 antigen of the bacteria can also be demonstrated by passive hemagglutination. PCR is used for a rapid presumptive diagnosis.

Treatment- Streptomycin, doxycycline, and chloramphenicol can be used.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

Type of stain Applications

Used to stain pathological specimens

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.

Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, M. avium, Nocardia etc.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, no neck, a thorax that has 3 segments and an abdomen with 10 segments.  They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague and hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: A patient presents with the following skin lesion. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a skin lesion that is red, edematous, and well-demarcated from the surrounding skin. These features are suggestive of erysipelas. 

Erysipelas is a skin infection involving superficial lymphatics. It is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (β-Hemolytic Group A Streptococci). It presents with raised, erythematous sharply demarcated rapidly spreading skin lesions, along with systemic symptoms. Legs and face are the most common sites affected.

Other options:

Option B: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) is caused by the exfoliative toxin and presents with peeling of the affected skin. Separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis, by a shearing force, indicating a plane of cleavage is called the Nikolsky sign. Thus, Nikolsky's sign is positive in SSSS.

Option C: Gas gangrene is a form of myonecrosis. It is a bacterial infection in which tissue gas is produced in gangrene. It is usually caused by Clostridium perfringens. The given image of gas gangrene shows necrotic bullae, erythema, and edema.

Option D: Erysipeloid is caused by Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae (Different from erysipelas). The most common site of involvement in erysipeloid is the fingers, leading to a condition known as “ seal finger” or “whale finger.”

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with lower abdominal pain and diarrhea. The stool examination finding is shown below. Which of the following is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of amoebic dysentery caused by Entamoeba histolytica and the given image shows hematophagous trophozoite of Entamoeba histolytica.

Clinical features of intestinal amebiasis:

  • Acute intestinal amebiasis- dysentery, lower abdominal discomfort, and flatulence.
  • Chronic amebiasis- low-grade symptoms such as occasional diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue.

A granulomatous lesion called an ameboma may form in the cecal or rectosigmoid areas of the colon which can resemble an adenocarcinoma of the colon.

Option A - Giardia is often asymptomatic, but in some cases can lead to fat malabsorption, dull epigastric pain, and flatulence.

Option B - Shigella causes bacillary dysentery which is characterised by fever and generalised abdominal tenderness.

Option D - Campylobacter presents with fever, pain, and watery diarrhea. The stool contains leucocytes and blood.

Metronidazole is used in the treatment of amoebiasis like amoebic colitis and amoebic liver abscess. It is well absorbed from the small intestine and only a small amount of the unabsorbed drug reaches the colon, which is insufficient to kill the cysts.

Hence, luminal agents like diloxanide furoate, nitazoxanide or iodoquinol are required for the eradication of cysts and trophozoites in the intestine.

questions.text: Which organism has the following cell wall structure?
questions.solution:
The presence of teichoic acid and lipoteichoic acid with a thick peptidoglycan layer is a feature of gram-positive bacteria.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with painful intermittent swelling of knee and elbow joints with recurrent throat infections in the recent past. An ASO titre is to be measured for diagnosis. Which type of test is used to measure ASO titre?
questions.solution:
ASO(Anti-streptolysin O) is measured by the latex agglutination test.(Option C)

The given clinical scenario of painful intermittent swelling of multiple joints (migratory polyarthritis) with a recent history of recurrent throat infections is suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. Group A β-hemolytic streptococci such as streptococcus pyogenes produce hemolysins such as streptolysin-O and streptolysin-S. They cause RBC membrane lysis which is responsible for β-hemolysis in blood agar. 

Antibodies against these hemolysins are formed in the body whose titre is used as a standard marker for retrospective diagnosis of streptococcal infections. An ASO titer of >200 IU/mL is diagnostic of most streptococcal infections except pyoderma and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). It was previously detected by a neutralisation test but is now completely replaced by the latex agglutination and nephelometry methods.

In latex agglutination tests, polystyrene latex particles (0.8–1 μm in diameter) are used as carrier molecules capable of adsorbing several types of antigens. A drop of the patient’s serum (containing antibody) is added to a drop of latex solution coated with the antigen and the card is rotated for uniform mixing. A positive result is indicated by the formation of visible clumps. It is a simple, rapid card test.

Anti-DNase-B antibody titer of more than 300–350 IU/ mL is diagnostic of PSGN and pyoderma. 

Other options -

Option A) Tube agglutination test - Examples are - 

  • Widal test for typhoid fever
  • Standard agglutination test(SAT) for acute brucellosis
  • Coomb’s antiglobulin test
  • All heterophile antibody tests       

Option B) Precipitation test examples are -

  • Slide flocculation tests of syphilis - VDRL and RPR tests
  • Elek’s gel precipitation test - Detecting toxigenic strains of diphtheria 

Option D) An example of a complement fixation test is the Wasserman test, formerly used for serological diagnosis of syphilis.

questions.text: A patient presents with blisters on the hand and axillary lymphadenopathy. What history will you enquire about with this patient?

choices.text: History of similar complaint in family members

questions.solution:
Patient with blister on the hand followed by axillary lymphadenopathy is more suggestive of Cat scratch disease, a disease caused by Bartonella henselae, hence we should ask about the history of exposure to cat.

Cat-scratch disease is also known as subacute regional lymphadenitis. It is acquired following contact with infected animals, commonly cats. 

Regional lymph nodes demonstrate:

  • Follicular hyperplasia with circumscribed central stellate necrosis with neutrophils
  • Surrounded by palisading histiocytes (suppurative granulomas)
  • Sinuses packed with monocytoid B cells
  • Usually, there are no perifollicular and intrafollicular epithelioid cells

Bartonella henselae also causes bacillary angiomatosis and bacillary peliosis in HIV-infected people.

questions.text: A child presents with a fever, hepatosplenomegaly and a rash. The characteristic 'owl eye' inclusion bodies are noted on further evaluation. Which of the following is the best specimen to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a child with fever, hepatosplenomegaly and rash along with owl’s eye inclusion bodies are intranuclear basophilic inclusion bodies seen in Congenital cytomegalovirus infection. Congenital CMV infection is diagnosed by detection of virus in the saliva or urine (saliva > urine), within the first two weeks of life. If culture is required then urine samples are better than saliva. PCR assays can be used to detect small amounts of CMV DNA in the urine.

Cytomegalovirus is a type of herpes virus, which causes severe disease in immunocompromised patients. In most other cases, it is inapparent and marked by prolonged latency with intermittent reactivation.

Diagnosis:

  • IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV). 
  • Avidity level measured by avidity index is used to describe the percentage of IgG bound to the antigen after being treated with denaturing agents.These assays are based on the fact that low avidity IgG antibodies are present during the first few months after the infection and avidity increases over time indicating maturation of the immune response. So the presence of high avidity IgG denotes a past infection rather than a primary one. Low avidity IgG signals a primary infection within the last 3-4 months. 
  • IgM detection can be used as an indicator of acute infection, but it lacks specificity for primary infection. This is because it persists for years in some individuals and is also produced during reactivation.

The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV). The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever (most common), leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia.

questions.text: Specific binding of the HIV to the CD4 receptor occurs via which of these structures?
questions.solution:
The specific binding of the HIV to the CD4 receptor is by the envelope glycoprotein gp120.

Other options:

Option B - Cell fusion occurs via binding to gp41. Cell fusion is essential for infection to take place.

Options C and D - Binding to CD4 receptor requires the participation of co-receptors, CXCR 4 for T cell - tropic HIV strains and CCR 5 for macrophage-tropic strains.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents with a history of progressive breathlessness and difficulty in breathing since 3 months. A chest X-ray shows a cavitary lesion in the lower lobe of the lung. Lobectomy was done and the histopathology image is given below. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological slide are suggestive of hydatid disease of the lung caused by Echinococcus granulosus.

Hydatid disease most commonly occurs in the liver, the second most common being the lungs. The clinical features of hydatid disease of the lung include breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, and even pneumothorax. Treatment includes wedge resection or lobectomy and administration of albendazole. Pre and postoperative chemotherapy with albendazole is recommended for 2 years after curative surgery.

Casoni’s test is a type I hypersensitivity reaction used in the diagnosis of hydatid disease. It involves the intradermal injection of 0.25 ml of sterilized fluid from hydatid cysts/human cysts on the forearm. An equal volume of saline is injected into the other forearm as control. It is observed for the next 30 minutes and again after 1-2 days. The fluid used for the test is sterilized by Seitz filtration. A wheal response at the injection site occurring within 20 minutes is considered positive. It is followed by a secondary reaction 8 hours later. The test is not often used nowadays due to its non-specificity.

The hydatid cyst wall consists of 3 layers:

  • Pericyst- the outer dense fibrous capsule that is formed as a result of host inflammatory response.
  • Ectocyst- the intermediate layer consisting of acellular, chitinous, laminated hyaline material.
  • Endocyst- the inner germinal layer that is cellular and consists of a number of nuclei embedded in protoplasmic mass and is extremely thin. It is the vital layer of the cyst and it is the site of asexual reproduction giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.

The below image shows the histology of hydatid cyst.

questions.text: A truck driver came with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. He is suspected to have a hard chancre. Motility of the most likely causative organism can be detected by which of the following microscopes?
questions.solution:
Hard chancre / syphilitic chancre is caused by Treponema pallidum. The motility of the organism can be demonstrated by dark ground/ field microscopy. 

Dark ground microscopy can be used to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present to visualize Treponema pallidum. Dark-field microscopy images have a dark background with a refractile organism. The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies. It is generally less sensitive.

The image given below shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by dark ground microscopy.

Various types of Spirochetes and their appearances under a dark ground microscope:

  • Treponemes generally are short and slender with regular and sharp spirals.
  • Leptospira have a large number of closely wound spirals and characteristic hooked ends.
  • Borrelia is large with irregular and wide open coils.

 

Other options:

Option B: Electron microscopy is not commonly used for diagnostics in laboratories. It generally helps in appreciating viral structures. 

Option C: Light microscopes are commonly used in the labs to visualize the stained smears of various bacteria, and fungi in 100x magnification. They are also used during the examination of stool specimens for identifying ova, eggs, or larvae.

Option D: A fluorescent microscope uses fluorescent dyes like auramine-rhodamine to appreciate Mycobacterial species and malarial parasites.

questions.text: An unknown disease of suspected infectious origin has come up in your town. As a microbiologist, you collect the relevant samples and detect the etiological cause. Which of the following types of PCR would you do?
questions.solution:
Multiplex PCR can be used to identify an unknown infectious agent.

Types of PCR:

  • Multiplex PCR: Primers to more than one pathogen are used simultaneously and hence multiple products are obtained. 
  • Nested PCR: It involves the sequential use of two primer sets. The first primer set is used for amplification and the amplicon obtained is then used as a target sequence for second amplification. This ensures specificity. Used in GeneXpert to detect Mycobacterium TB and resistance to rifampicin.
  • Quantitative PCR: Apart from just detecting the target sequences, it also tells the number of such target sequences. We can quantify the HIV viral load with this technique.
  • Reverse transcriptase PCR: The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesize a complimentary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR. Unlike conventional PCR which can only amplify DNA, this one can even amplify RNA. It is used to detect H1N1 from the Nasopharyngeal swab.
  • Real-time PCR: This helps quantify the PCR and gives an estimate of the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes. It is also known as qPCR (Quantitative PCR).

questions.text: A researcher is studying the cell wall synthesis of a Gram-positive bacterium. During the experiment, they discovered a mutation that disrupts the enzyme transpeptidase. Which antibiotic does this mutation confer resistance to?
questions.solution:
Penicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics inhibit the enzyme transpeptidase, which is responsible for cross-linking peptidoglycan strands. A mutation disrupting this enzyme would lead to resistance to penicillin.

Vancomycin inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of peptidoglycan precursors, preventing their incorporation into the cell wall, rather than directly affecting the transpeptidase enzyme.

Bacitracin interferes with the dephosphorylation of bactoprenol, a carrier molecule that transports peptidoglycan precursors across the cell membrane.

Daptomycin disrupts cell membrane function rather than inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

questions.text:
Which of the following are acid-fast staining organisms?
  1. Nocardia
  2. Actinomyces
  3. Mycobacterium leprae
  4. Clostridium perfringens
  5. Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  6. Isospora belli
questions.solution:
Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, and Cytoisospora belli are acid-fast staining organisms.

Acid-fast staining is based on the principle that tubercle bacilli resist decolourization with acids after staining with aniline dyes. Acid fastness is attributed to the variety of fatty acids, alcohols, and lipids in the tubercle bacilli. Acid-fast organisms usually contain mycolic acid, which is acid-fast in the free state.  The steps to carry out acid-fast staining as modified by Ziehl and Neelsen are:

  1. The slide is stained with carbolfuchsin along with the application of heat.
  2. It is then decolourized with 20% sulphuric acid. Later methylene blue is used for counterstaining.
  3. The acid-fast bacteria retain the fuchsin colour, while other organisms take up the counterstain.

The genus Nocardia are aerobic organisms and weakly acid-fast positive rods. They stain with carbolfuchsin and retain it when 1-4% sulfuric acid is used.

 

Mycobacterium leprae, the causative agent of leprosy is a gram-positive bacillus. It is acid-fast when 5% sulphuric acid is used instead of 20%.

 

Cryptosporidium parvum, commonly causes diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals. The oocysts in the stool can be visualized by modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining. It appears as red acid-fast spheres. It can also be used for specimens such as sputum and bronchial wash.

 

Isospora belli is a coccidian parasite that can cause protracted diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. Modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining reveals pink-colored acid-fast oocyst in stool samples.

 

Actinomyces are gram-positive, anaerobic, and filamentous bacteria that are non-acid-fast in contrast to Nocardia.

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.

questions.text: A young intravenous drug abuser presents with a 1-week history of malaise, fatigue, and rigors. On examination, a high-pitched murmur was heard loudest at the fourth intercostal space in the parasternal region and a cutaneous lesion as seen in the image below was observed. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is infective endocarditis. The most common cause of this disease in intravenous drug users is Staphylococcus aureus.

Infective endocarditis is caused due to an infection of cardiac valves. The most common causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus.

Infective endocarditis in patients who inject drugs commonly affects the tricuspid valve. In the case of tricuspid regurgitation patients present with high-pitched murmur heard loudest at the fourth intercostal space in the parasternal region.

The image in the vignette is of Osler's nodes. Osler nodes are painful, with raised lesions of the fingers, toe, and feet. They are peripheral lesions seen in patients with infective endocarditis. 

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Clinical criteria
  2. Pathologic criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

Presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Clinical Criteria

Major Criteria

1. Positive blood culture

Typical microorganism for IE from 2 separate blood cultures.

(or)

Persistently positive blood culture of an organism consistent with IE from:

  • Blood cultures drawn >12 h apart.
  • All of 3 or a majority of ≥4 separate blood cultures, with first and last drawn at least 1 h apart.

(or)

Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetti or phase I IgG antibody titer of >1:800.

 

2. Evidence of endocardial involvement

Echocardiographic identification of oscillating intracardiac mass on valve or implant or in the path of regurgitant jets

(or)

New Valvular regurgitation

Minor Criteria

1. Predisposing heart lesion or intravenous drug use

2. Fever ≥38.0°C (≥100.4°F)

3. Vascular lesions: Major arterial emboli, septic pulmonary infarcts, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage, conjunctival hemorrhages, Janeway lesions.

4. Immunological evidence: Glomerulonephritis, Osler nodes, Roth spots, rheumatoid factor.

5. Microbiologic evidence: Positive blood culture but not meeting the major criterion, or serologic evidence of active infection with an organism consistent with infective endocarditis.

 

Pathological Criteria

1. Microorganisms demonstrated by culture or histologic examination, in vegetation, embolus from vegetation, or intracardiac abscess

(or)

2. Histologic confirmation of active endocarditis in vegetation or intracardiac abscess

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established, if symptoms resolve and do not recur with ≤4 days of antibiotic therapy, or if surgery or autopsy after ≤4 days of antimicrobial therapy yields no histologic evidence of endocarditis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy returned from a birthday party and began vomiting 4-5 hours later, followed by a few episodes of loose stools but had no fever. Other children who had attended the party reported a similar illness. Food samples were collected and sent for toxin detection by a test based on the following principle. This test is known as:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Sandwich ELISA. The above clinical scenario is suggestive of food poisoning caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

The symptoms of food poisoning caused by S aureus appear within 1-8 hours. Multiple people are exposed to the pathogen from a common source and present with vomiting, loose stools but no fever. Foods from outbreaks of food poisoning is examined for the presence of staphylococcal enterotoxin A (SEA) by a sandwich ELISA.

ELISA (Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) involves the use of an immunosorbent, which is an absorbing material that is specific for one of the components of the reaction, either the antigen or antibody. This may be a particulate phase (cellulose or agarose), or a solid phase (polystyrene, polyvinyl, or polycarbonate tubes or microwells). ELISA is done using 96-well microtitre plates suitable for automation.

Sandwich ELISA is used for antigen detection in the patient samples. The antigen is sandwiched between two layers of antibodies - capture and detection antibodies.

The following steps are followed in Sandwich ELISA:

  1. The capture antibody is immobilized on a microtiter well.
  2. A sample containing antigen is added and allowed to react with the immobilized antibody.
  3. After the well is washed, a second enzyme-linked antibody (Detecting antibody) specific to the antigen is added and allowed to react with the bound antigen.
  4. After any free second antibody is removed by washing, the substrate is added. This substrate is converted by the enzyme to detectable colored form and the colored reaction product is measured.

Other options:

Cassette ELISA: Here, each specimen is tested in a separate disposable cassette and gives rapid results (10-15 minutes). There is no need for microplate washers or readers and the result can be read visually. Example: Dot Blot Assay used for the detection of HIV type 1 and 2 antibodies.

Competitive ELISA: Both the unknown antigen (sample) and the known antigen (standard) compete with each other for a fixed amount of antibody.

Indirect ELISA: Antibody in the sample can be detected or quantitatively measured using this method. Serum or some other sample containing primary antibody (Ab1) is added to an antigen-coated microtiter well and allowed to react. Enzyme-conjugated secondary anti-isotype antibody (Ab2) is added which binds to the primary antibody.

The given image shows steps followed in different types of ELISA.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman was diagnosed with right leg cellulitis and was admitted to the hospital for 3 days. She was prescribed clindamycin. Two days after her discharge, she developed diarrhea and abdominal pain. Her temperature was 38.8 degrees Celcius. Her blood reports are given below. What is the most probable etiological agent?
  • Hemoglobin- 12 g/dL
  • WBC count of 18,000/mm3
  • CRP of 160 mg/L
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with hospital-acquired diarrhea (nosocomial) following antibiotic administration is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis due to Clostridium difficile. 

Clostridium difficile is the most common cause of infectious diarrhea in nosocomial infection. 

It is the most common antibiotic-associated diarrhea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, which causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora, leading to colonization of C. difficile.

Clinical features:

  • Lower abdominal pain with loose watery diarrhea.
  • Fever, leukocytosis
  • In some patients, the disease may progress to life-threatening pseudomembranous colitis

Investigations:

  • Nucleic acid amplification tests, including polymerase chain reaction assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool 
  • Stool culture in selective media
  • Demonstrating toxin by cell cytotoxin cultures
  • Toxin gene identification by enzyme immunoassay
  • Colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy reveals a characteristic pseudomembrane.

Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PCR assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool, have now been approved for diagnostic purposes and appear to be both rapid and sensitive while retaining high specificity.

Oral vancomycin, metronidazole, and fidaxomicin are used for the treatment of pseudomembranous colitis, depending on its severity. 

First choice treatment of C. difficile colitis:

Severity Treatment
Mild to moderate Oral vancomycin OR fidaxomicin
Severe (WBC >15,000/cu.mm, Creatinine >1.5 times baseline) Oral vancomycin OR fidaxomicin
Severe, complicated (shock, ileus, toxic megacolon) Oral vancomycin + IV metronidazole ± Rectal vancomycin
Recurrent/ multiple episodes Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT)

 

Other options: Escherichia coli, Norovirus, Rotavirus are all causes of Traveller's diarrhea.

Other causes of Nosocomial diarrhea:

  • Clostridium perfringens,
  • Klebsiella oxytoca,
  • Staphylococcus aureus.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: A 5 yr old boy presents with headache, fever and vomiting. On examination, multiple small vesicles are present on the posterior pharyngeal wall.  He is diagnosed with herpangina and is started on supportive therapy. Whats is herpangina caused by?
questions.solution:
Herpangina is caused by Coxsackie A virus, a large subgroup of the enteroviruses.

Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis is a common clinical manifestation of coxsackie A infection in children, but it can also be caused by Coxsackievirus B virus, echoviruses or enterovirus 71. The lesions are small vesicles on the fauces and the posterior pharyngeal wall that break down to form ulcers. 

 

The image shows palatal ulcers in herpangina.

questions.text: The milk ring test is found to be positive for a sample of milk. Which organism has it most likely been contaminated with?
questions.solution:
Milk ring test (MRT) is positive for Brucella. It is used for the detection of infected animals in dairy farms. 

A sample of whole milk is mixed with a drop of Brucella antigen and incubated at 70 °C for 40–50 min.

If antibodies are present in the milk, the bacilli are agglutinated and rise with the cream to form a blue ring at the top, leaving the rest of the milk unstained (MRT positive). If antibodies are absent, the solution remains uniformly blue (MRT negative).

questions.text: Identify the organism & the stain used from the image given below :
questions.solution:
The given image shows Helicobacter pylori under Warthin-Starry stain.

H.pylori is a gram-negative motile rod with lophotrichous flagella. The gastric antrum is the commonest site of colonization. Infection is confined to the gastric mucosa in the stomach or in areas of gastric metaplasia and heteroplasia in the duodenum. 

In some patients, H.pylori causes mild acute gastritis lasting for about two weeks. In others, it can cause peptic ulcer disease which in later stages may lead to chronic atrophic gastritis. This is a risk factor for gastric malignancies like adenocarcinoma and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphomas. 

The urea breath test is a rapid diagnostic procedure used to identify infection, as H.pylori has a unique feature of the production of urease.

The given image shows H.pylori on gastric mucosa stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain. The bacteria are present only in the mucus overlying the gastric mucosa and do not actually invade the mucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria demonstrates tumbling type of motility at 25 °C, but is non-motile at 37 °C?
questions.solution:
Listeria monocytogenes demonstrates tumbling end-over-end motility at 22–28 °C but becomes non-motile at 37 °C. 

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus. These rods are facultatively intracellular and move from cell to cell using the host cell actin framework. It can grow at low refrigeration temperatures. They show tumbling motility at 25°C. But, at 37°C, it is non-motile because the peritrichous flagella are produced by the bacillus optimally between 20°C and 30°C.

The image below shows the tumbling motility of L. monocytogenes.

Listeria can overcome the food preservation process since it grows at 4°C, with low pH, and high salt concentration.

Listeriosis can present as gastroenteritis in healthy adults. It usually develops within 48 hours of ingestion of a large inoculum in contaminated food. It can also lead to the formation of an abscess, pharyngitis, pneumonia, and endocarditis. It leads to neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and meningoencephalitis in the elderly and immunocompromised people. Listeriosis in pregnancy can lead to abortion and stillbirth.

Most laboratories do not routinely culture Listeria from stool samples. The diagnosis of systemic listeriosis rests on the isolation of the organism in cultures of blood and spinal fluid.

Ampicillin plus gentamicin is often recommended for therapy. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is the drug of choice for central nervous system infections in patients who are allergic to penicillin.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady presented with itchy vaginal discharge. Microscopic examination revealed organisms as shown. Which of the following is true regarding the infection?

choices.text: The organism shows jerky motility with its 2 flagella
Presents as fishy odor and curdy precipitate
Green kit is used for syndromic treatment

questions.solution:
The above scenario of a patient with itchy vaginal discharge with the presence of flagellated trophozoites on microscopy indicated a diagnosis of trichomonas vaginalis. Green kit containing secnidazole is used for the syndrome treatment of trichomonas vaginalis.

Trichomonas is transmitted from person to person. Trophozoites are infective forms. They exhibit jerky motility by means of 5 flagella. It classically causes petechial hemorrhage and mucosal capillary dilatation giving a 'strawberry cervix' appearance.

Diagnosis can be established by a wet mount smear of vaginal discharge. In doubtful cases, culture can be done to establish the diagnosis.Treatment of trichomonas can be done with a Tablet Metronidazole or tinidazole 2gm single dose or secnidazole 1gm daily for 2 days. Partner treatment is required when symptomatic and sexual contact with an infected partner should be avoided.

questions.text: A 2 year old child is brought to the OPD with oral and perioral lesions as seen in the image below. Similar lesions were also found on his palms and soles. What is the probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of hand, foot, and mouth disease that is caused by coxsackie A virus.

Hand, foot, and mouth disease initially begins with fever and sore throat following which blisters develop over the oral cavity, hands and feet.

It usually occurs in children but may also occur in adults. It is a self limiting disease and subsides in 1-2 weeks.

The following images show lesions affecting hands and feet:

Other options:

Option B: Molluscum contagiosum presents as umbilicated nodules and not vesicles.

Option C: Parvovirus B19 infection occurs usually in children 5–10 years causing erythema infectiosum. It is also known as fifth disease. It begins as a prominent erythema of the cheeks- slapped cheek disease, spreading to the trunk and limbs, followed by lymphadenopathy and arthralgia

Option D: Streptococcus causes red sores around the mouth and the nose in impetigo. It forms a characteristic honey-coloured scab and is not associated with lesions on palms and soles. The given image shows impetigo.

questions.text: Which among the following is a high-level disinfectant?
questions.solution:
Glutaraldehyde is an example of a high-level disinfectant.

High-level disinfectant- This is a chemical that kills all microbial pathogens except a large number of spores. It may have some activity against a smaller number of spores if the contact time is increased. Eg- Glutaraldehyde, hydrogen peroxide.

Intermediate level disinfectant: A chemical that kills all microbial pathogens including mycobacteria and non enveloped viruses except spores. Eg- Alcohol, iodophors.

Low-level disinfectants:They kill only vegetative bacteria, fungi, and lipid enveloped viruses, e.g Benzalkonium chloride

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby was brought with complaints of loose stools for 2 weeks. Which of the following organisms is likely to cause this disease?
questions.solution:
Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes infantile bacterial diarrhea. It is nontoxigenic and noninvasive.

E. coli is the second most common cause of diarrhea in the pediatric age group. Rotavirus is the most common cause. EPEC causes persistent watery diarrhea which is self-limiting.

EPEC adheres to the mucosal cells of the small bowel and causes loss of microvilli (effacement). This leads to formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures and occasionally may cause entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells.

Pathogenicity requires the presence of two important factors:

  •  Bundle forming pilus encoded by plasmid containing EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
  •  Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenecity island.

Other options:

Option B: Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC) produce two potent toxins, verocytotoxin (VT) or Shiga-like toxin (SLT). Especially in young children and the elderly, they cause diarrhea ranging from mild to fatal hemorrhagic colitis and hemorrhagic uremic syndrome (HUS). EHEC primarily targets vascular endothelial cells leading to HUS. E.coli serotype 0157: H7 is associated with EHEC diarrhea and its complications.

Option C: Enterotoxigenic E. coli causes endemic diarrhoea in developing countries and travellers diarrhoea. ETEC serotypes responsible for diarrhea are mostly 06, 08, 015, 025, 027, 0167. It attaches to intestinal mucosa with fimbriae called colonization factor antigens. The pathology is due to the heat-labile toxin (LT) produced by some and heat-stable toxin (ST) produced by others.

Option D: Enteroinvasive E.coli (EIEC) has clinical features are similar to shigellosis. It produces disease by invading the intestinal mucosa.

questions.text: The structure of which of the following viruses is depicted in this image?
questions.solution:
The virus depicted in the above image is the influenza virus.

The influenza virus is a segmented, negative-sense/negative-strand RNA virus. It belongs to the family of orthomyxoviruses. The hemagglutinin and neuraminidase receptors are present as two different spikes on the envelope. 

Influenza viruses are classified into A, B, and C serotypes depending on the antigenic structure. Patients infected with the influenza virus present with a wide range of symptoms such as fever, headache, and myalgia to full-blown pneumonia.

questions.text: A 50 year old man came with complaints of nausea, vomiting, dizziness and blurring of vision of sudden onset.  There were  no associated co-morbidities. On probing, history of ingestion of home- canned beans is present. Patient had developed descending flaccid paralysis on 2nd day. A diagnosis of botulism is made. Which category of bio-terrorism  does the causative agent belongs to?
questions.solution:
Botulism is caused by Clostridium Botulinum and it belongs to Category A of bio- terrorism agents.

The botulinum toxin is highly potent, with 1 gram capable of killing 1 million people if dispersed effectively.

The toxin inhibits the release of acetylcholine by preventing its vesicle fusion with the motor neuron membrane, resulting in flaccid paralysis. Transmission can occur via contaminated food, aerosolized toxin, or growth in wounds, with the latter two relevant for bioterrorism.

 Patients initially develop multiple cranial nerve palsies, followed by descending flaccid paralysis. Severe cases may involve complete muscular collapse, loss of gag reflex, and respiratory failure, requiring weeks to months of ventilator support.

The diagnosis is suspected based on clinical presentation and mouse bio-assay and immune-assay. Treatment is mainly supportive.

Bioterrorism is the deliberate release of an agent by attackers that causes one or more of a variety of different diseases. The agents of bioterrorism are classified into 3 categories:

  • Category A bioterrorism agents are those which are easily transmitted from one person to the other and are associated with high mortality rates and thus have the potential to cause major public health impacts. Examples include Bacillus anthracis, Clostridium botulinum, and Yersinia pestis.
  • Category B bioterrorism agents are those which are moderately easy to disseminate and are associated with moderate morbidity and low mortality rates. Examples include Coxiella burnetti and Brucella.
  • Category C bioterrorism agents are those which are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future due to ease of availability, high mortality and morbidity rates, and ease of production and dissemination. Examples include Nipah and Hanta viruses.

questions.text: A chronic asthmatic patient who is on inhaled steroids presents with a history of a burning sensation on eating hot or spicy food and the following findings are seen. What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of oral steroid use along with a lesion on the tongue points towards a diagnosis of candida infection.

Erythematous (atrophic) candidiasis appears as a red, raw-looking lesion. It may or may not be related to pseudo membranes. On the tongue, there is a loss of the lingual papillae, leaving a smooth area. It can occur after long-term corticosteroids or antibiotics usage or those with HIV. Other names for this condition include acute atrophic oral candidiasis and antibiotic sore tongue.

Cutaneous and mucosal infections manifest as thrush affecting the tongue, lips, gums, and palate. It is seen as a patchy to confluent whitish pseudomembranous lesion and is commonly associated with AIDS. Candida may also invade the vaginal mucosa leading to vulvovaginitis, and the nails, and around the nail plate leading to onychomycosis. Mucocutaneous manifestations are managed with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole.

Other options:

Burning mouth syndrome (BMS) is a burning sensation in the mouth with no underlying dental or medical cause where no related signs of disease are found in the mouth.

Migratory glossitis / geographic tongue is due to the rapid loss and regrowth of filiform papillae of the tongue. It is a benign inflammatory condition of the tongue associated with psoriasis and reactive arthritis. Geographic tongue, though consistent with the clinical image is not the best fit considering the clinical history. It is usually asymptomatic but can be occasionally associated with a sore tongue.

Oral lichen planus is associated with Wickham striae in the oral cavity. They are fine white lines in a lacy or fern-like pattern that cross the plaques in lichen planus.
